awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Northeast Analysis Network
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides funding for participation in the conference "The Northeast Analysis Network" that will be held at University of Connecticut in Fall 2019, University of Rochester in Fall 2020, Syracuse University in Fall 2021, SUNY-Albany in Fall 2022.
 
The conferences focus on recent developments in Analysis, in a broad spectrum of fields including harmonic analysis, dynamical systems, geometric function theory, nonlinear partial differential equations, and operator algebras.   At each conference, there will be two magnet lectures by a leader researcher, and many short talks by junior conference participants.  The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity known to target groups through a number of different activities.   More information will be made available at: https://sites.google.com/site/northeastanalysisnetwork/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The project supported the Northeast Analysis Network (NAN) 2023 workshop in Rochester, NY, on Sept. 23-24, 2023. The NAN conferences are designed to promote connections and foster a community among mathematicians working on Analysis in New York state and the greater Northeast Region
on an ongoing basis.  The meetings are intended to benefit all analysts in the Northeast region, but particularly junior researchers on either side of, but close to, the Ph.D., including graduate students and postdoctoral researchers.       In-person interactions among these junior researchers, and between them and a group of more established mathematicians, will contribute to their professional development as mathematicians and as future members of mathematical sciences-related professions.

At NAN 2023, a diverse group of speakers (in terms of home institution, professional status and gender) presented 13 talks. There were 2 Excelsior Lectures by Prof. Lillian Pierce; a talk/professional development activity on applying for grants by Matthew Badger; and 10 other lectures on a range of topics in Analysis, including analysis on manifolds, partial differential equations, complex analysis, and Fourier analysis on Euclidean spaces and on locally compact groups. In all, over the two days of the workshop, there were at least 37 attendees. Time was set aside for participants to meet and talk in outdoor settings during coffee breaks and meals. An anonymous survey of participants indicated satisfaction with the workshop, including the Excelsior Lectures,  the professional development activity, and the general format and organization.


Last Modified: 06/11/2024
Modified by: Allan T Greenleaf

At NAN 2023, a diverse  group of speakers (in terms of home institution, professional status  and gender) presented 13 talks. There were 2 Excelsior Lectures by Prof.  Lillian Pierce; a talk/professional development activity on applying  for grants by Matthew Badger; and 10 other lectures on a range of topics  in Analysis, including analysis on manifolds, partial differential  equations, complex analysis, and Fourier analysis on Euclidean spaces  and on locally compact groups. An anonymous survey of participants indicated satisfaction  with the workshop, including the Excelsior Lectures, the professional  development activity, and the general format and organization.
